titlepage.titleproper: Rockwell International, Collins General Aviation Division Publications, 1979-1984
titlepage.subtitle:
A Collection in
Special Collections Ms1994-012

defitem.label: Processed by: Angelica Rivera, Student Worker, and Laurel Rozema, Archivist,

did.head: Descriptive Summary
did.repository: Special Collections, Virginia Tech, Blacksburg, Va.
did.unittitle: Rockwell International, Collins General Aviation Division Publications, 1979-1984
did.abstract: Twenty-one booklets from the Collins General Aviation Division of Rockwell International contain information regarding products of the division, such as Electronic Flight Instrument system and Weather Radar systems. One booklet is from Dorne & Margolin, Inc., about their antennas and accessories.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: Permission to publish material from Rockwell International, Collins General Aviation Division Publications must be obtained from Special Collections, Virginia Tech.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Researchers wishing to cite this collection should include the following information: Rockwell International, Collins General Aviation Division Publications, Ms1994-012, Special Collections, Virginia Tech, Blacksburg, Va.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: The Rockwell International, Collins General Aviation Division Publications were donated to Special Collections in March and May 1994.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: The processing, arrangement, and description of the Rockwell International, Collins General Aviation Division Publications was commenced and completed in February 2020.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical Note
bioghist.p: The North American Rockwell Corporation formed in 1967 by the merger of North American Aviation, Inc., founded as a holding company for a number of aviation companies in 1928, with the Rockwell-Standard Corporation, founded in 1919 by Colonel Willard Rockwell. The company became Rockwell International in 1973, when it also acquired Collins Radio Co., founded in 1933 by Arthur Collins. The company made the rocket engines for Saturn V and several Space Shuttle orbiters for NASA.
In 1996, Boeing purchased the defence and aerospace divisions of Rockwell, and in 2001, the conglomerate separated into Rockwell Collins and Rockwell Automation.

Source:
Editors of Encyclopaedia Britannica. "Rockwell International Corporation." Encyclopedia Britannica. Published May 20, 2015. https://www.britannica.com/topic/Rockwell-International-Corporation. Accessed February 13, 2020.
Braband, Ken C. The First 50 Years: A History of Collins Radio Company and the Collins Divisions of Rockwell International. Cedar Rapids, Iowa: Communications Department, Avionics Group, Rockwell International, 1983.
"In Brief: Rockwell to Change Name to Rockwell Automation after Rockwell Collins spinoff." Military and Aerospace Electronics. Published April 1, 2001. https://www.militaryaerospace.com/communications/article/16710689/in-brief. Accessed February 13, 2020.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Twenty-one booklets from the Collins General Aviation Division of Rockwell International contain information regarding products of the division, such as Electronic Flight Instrument system and Weather Radar systems. One booklet is from Dorne & Margolin, Inc., about their antennas and accessories.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection is organized by type.

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Materials
separatedmaterial.p: The First 50 Years: A History of Collins Radio Company and the Collins Divisions of Rockwell International by Ken C. Braband was seperated to the Rare Books Collection.
